results.title: Born different
results.brief_description: A documentary about the mentally handicapped children cared for at the Melbourne Kew Cottages. Founded in 1887 mainly owing to the campaigning of Dr J.V. McCleery, the Superintendant of the Kew Mental Hospital, the cottages are now one of the largest government institutions for the care and training of mentally handicapped children. Gives an unusual insight into this little-understood problem in talks with nurses who tell of the activities at the centre. Parents of handicapped children explain what these children have meant in their lives, and of the decision to send the youngsters to the cottages. Narrated by Gerald Lyons.

results.title: Born Chinese
results.brief_description: One quarter of the world’s population is Chinese, yet their habits and customs are little known. This is a story of a Chinese family and the life that surrounds them. They left China soon after the Revolution and now live in one of the huge government housing blocks in the thriving British colony of Hong Kong, where since the mass exodus from China it is possible to mingle with greater freedom than ever before with people born and brought up in China. Tells of their domestic, social, business, and cultural life. Narrated by Anthony Lawrence.

results.title: Boring for water in South Africa
results.brief_description: An instructional film showing procedures in drilling water bores in arid areas of South Africa, from the geological survey to the setting up and operation of the drill rig. Includes drill-bit sharpening, operation and erection of a windmill to pump out water.

results.title: Borgo a Mozzano
results.creator_credit: Michele Gandin, Report Films and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: During the last three thousand years the commune of Borgo a Mozzano in Tuscany has often been touched by history but somehow, now, it has stopped growing. As an experiment in raising the standard of living an agronomist was called in. But peasants are conservative and it takes time to win them over, but at last this was done and a new way of life began to unfold.

results.title: The Borders: where Scotland and England meet
results.creator_credit: Mike Pavett, Robin Crichton and Edinburgh Film Productions
results.brief_description: Examines the agricultural and industrial development of the border regions of Scotland and England, and the growth of new houses and educational institutions. Highlights projects which have been implemented to attract population and encourage young people to stay instead of seeking careers and employment elsewhere.

results.title: Boomsville
results.creator_credit: Yvon Mallette, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An amusing diagnosis of big city growing pains. This film is an ironic view of town planning or rather, the lack of it and what has happened to our cities as a result. Done in cartoon animation, the film traces the growth of the typical city, from a tiny settlement in the vast North American wilderness to the car-clogged metropolis that so many cities are today. Awards: New York; Oberhousen; Les Menuires.

results.title: Boomerang = Bumerang
results.brief_description: Cartoon in which a butterfly causes trouble at a rocket station. This film is a satire on a military dictatorship and the perseverance of the human spirit. The soundtrack contains no music or dialogue, only sound effects. Animated by Branislav Nemet and Turido Paus.

results.title: Boom (Canada's Expo 67)
results.creator_credit: Alain Grothe and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows the rapid expansion of Montreal in the last few years due to the building of Expo 67 in that city. Views of the city are combined with a coverage of the Expo site in the process of construction. Narrated by Lorne Greene.

results.title: Books go walkabout
results.brief_description: The State Library Bookmobile. The librarian in charge and the driver bring a wide variety of books to places without a permanent library building: old people’s homes; small country schools and townships; isolated farms. Shows the fittings of the travelling library, the librarian answering queries and bringing batches of books specially requested for particular purposes.

results.title: Books for Beaver River
results.creator_credit: Donald Ginsberg, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: It took a boy with his eyes on the stars to show that even the best town is a poor town when it has no place for books. Beaver River, a farming community in north central Saskatchewan, has paved roads, a new school, a curling rink, and many television sets, but no place where a boy could find a book about the stars. In this film Beaver River gets its own library and, in the process, illustrates Saskatchewan’s regional library system which provides book loans at minimum costs to municipality and province. This film is historically good for the pictorial/architecture/general life style of such a country town of it’s time.
